Recall the definition of a monoid:
\pmb{ Definition:} Monoid. A monoid is a set . \(M\) together with a binary operation * with the properties. \\ \hspace*{1.5ex} (a) \(*\) is associative: . \((a*b)*c=a*(b*c) \textrm{ \textit{for}}\textrm{ \textit{$ $}}\textrm{ \textit{all}}\textrm{ \textit{$ $}}a,b,c\in M\), and. \\ \hspace*{1.5ex} (b) \(*\) has an identity:. \(\textrm{ \textit{there}}\textrm{ \textit{$ $}}\textrm{ \textit{exists}} e\in M\textrm{ \textit{$ $}}\textrm{ \textit{$\textrm{ such} \textrm{ that} \textrm{ for} \textrm{ all} $}}a\in M, a*e=e*a=a .\)
Note: Since the requirements for a group contain the requirements for a monoid, every group is a monoid.
Example 14.1.1Example 14.1.1.
The power set of any set together with any one of the operations intersection, union, or symmetric difference is a monoid.
The set of integers, \mathbb{ZQ}, with multiplication, is a monoid. With addition, \mathbb{ZQ} is also a monoid.
The set of \(n\times n\) matrices over the integers, \(M_n(\mathbb{Z})\), \(n\geq 2\), with matrix multiplication, is a monoid. This follows from the fact that matrix multiplication is associative and has an identity, \(I_n\). This is an example of a noncommutative monoid since there are matrices, A and B, for which \(A B \neq B A\).
\(\left[\mathbb{Z}_n,\times _n\right],n\geqslant 2\), is a monoid with identity 1.
Let \(X\) be a nonempty set. The set of all functions from X into X, often denoted \(X^X\) , is a monoid over function composition. In Chapter 7, we saw that function composition is associative. The function \(i:X\to X\) defined by \(i(a)=a\) is the identity element for this system. This is another example of a noncommutative monoid, provided \(\left| X\right|\) is greater than 1.
If X is finite, \(\left\left| X^X\right\right| =\left| X\right| ^{\left| X\right| }\) . For example, if \(B=\{0,1\}, \left\left| B^B\right\right| =4\). \pmb{ GENERAL CONCEPTS AND PROPERTIES OF MONOIDS}
Virtually all of the group concepts that were discussed in Chapter 11 are applicable to monoids. When we introduced subsystems, we saw that a submonoid of monoid M is a subset of M $---$that is, it itself is a monoid with the operation of M. To prove that a subset is a submonoid, you can apply the following algorithm.
\pmb{ Theorem/Algorithm 14.1.1.} Let. \([M; *]\) \textit{ be a monoid and K is a nonempty subset of M, K is a submonoid of M if and only if:}\\ (a) If\(a,b\in K\), then. \(a*b\in K\text (i. e., K \textrm{ \textit{is}}\textrm{ \textit{$ $}}\textrm{ \textit{closed}}\textrm{ \textit{$ $}}\textrm{ \textit{under}} \textrm{ *)}\), and. \\ (b) the identity of M belongs to K. .
Often we will want to discuss the smallest submonoid that includes a certain subset S of a monoid M. This submonoid can be defined recursively by the following definition.

\pmb{ MONOID ISOMORPHISMS}
Two monoids are isomorphic. if and only if there exists a translation rule between them so that any true proposition in one monoid is translated to a true proposition in the other.
14.1.3.
\(M=[\mathcal{P}\{1,2,3\},\cap ]\) is isomorphic to \(M_2=\left[\mathbb{Z}_2^3;\cdot \right]\), where the operation in \(M_2\) is componentwise mod 2. multiplication. A translation rule is that if \(A\subseteq \{1,2,3\}\), then it is translated to \(\left(d_1,d_2,d_3\right)\) where \(d_i=\left\{ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & \textrm{ if} i\in A \\ 0 & \textrm{ if} i\notin A \\ \end{array} \right.\).
